text:
<!channel>,
here comes the afternoon entertainment schedule :grin:

• *2 pm - 3 pm:* :snake: TA's will offer support in setting up your (Ana)conda environments and also try to solve your technical issues in the terminal ("command not found"... those things)
• *3 pm - 3.30 pm:* :martial_arts_uniform: introduction to Katas on <http://codewars.com|codewars.com>
• *4 pm - 6 pm*: Prework and general Q & A. Ask the TA's all your remaining questions about your prework (you know, :snail: :female_mage: :bus: :dart: :thermometer: :rock: :page_with_curl: :scissors: ) and all other questions you have for today
enjoy your lunch!

text:
:microscope: *LAB WORK REVIEW*:microscope:
Thank you for your first set of lab work these two days, it’s great to see you all set up with your tools and infrastructure for the course, plus getting used to submitting work via the student portal. The teaching team can see when your work comes in, who is late etc, but we also learn a lot from looking at your submitted work - what students are struggling with and if we need to provide direct feedback or more instruction. Things I learnt:
• one of you can lick their own elbow! :muscle:
• one of you has more than 16 cousins!  :glitch_crab:
• one of you agrees with me that cilantro/coriander tastes like soap :face_vomiting:
• theres an icehockey world championship that looks like a lot of fun! :ice_hockey_stick_and_puck:
• some of you like scuba diving and beaches and the photos of these destinations are amazing :diving_mask:
• one of you has a friend dressed as a superhero :male_superhero:
Feedback
• read the instructions on each lab carefully. If you are asked to write a .txt file, we expect to see a text file in the github repo. 
• when we say fun fact… we really do mean something fun, use your imagination :) 
• submit the url as well as pushing the content to your repo - otherwise we cant see you have completed the work! 
• please run all cells in your notebook before pushing to github 
• if displaying any images in your notebook, the image file will also need to be pushed to the github repo 
• always name your jupyter notebook files before pushing to github

elements.text: LAB WORK REVIEW

Thank you for your first set of lab work these two days, it’s great to see you all set up with your tools and infrastructure for the course, plus getting used to submitting work via the student portal. The teaching team can see when your work comes in, who is late etc, but we also learn a lot from looking at your submitted work - what students are struggling with and if we need to provide direct feedback or more instruction. Things I learnt:
one of you can lick their own elbow!
one of you has more than 16 cousins!
one of you agrees with me that cilantro/coriander tastes like soap
theres an icehockey world championship that looks like a lot of fun!
some of you like scuba diving and beaches and the photos of these destinations are amazing
one of you has a friend dressed as a superhero
Feedback
read the instructions on each lab carefully. If you are asked to write a .txt file, we expect to see a text file in the github repo.
when we say fun fact… we really do mean something fun, use your imagination :)
submit the url as well as pushing the content to your repo - otherwise we cant see you have completed the work!
please run all cells in your notebook before pushing to github
if displaying any images in your notebook, the image file will also need to be pushed to the github repo
always name your jupyter notebook files before pushing to github
